title: EGSYS (Evaluation of Guidelines in SYncope Study) Score for Syncope
description: Predicts likelihood that syncope is of cardiac cause to help emergency clinicians with screening and risk stratification in patients presenting with syncope.

parameters.name: abnormal_ecg_heart_disease
parameters.description: Abnormal EKG and/or heart disease present

parameters.name: syncope_during_effort
parameters.description: Syncope occurred during physical effort or exertion

parameters.name: syncope_supine_position
parameters.description: Syncope occurred while in supine (lying down) position

parameters.name: autonomic_prodromes
parameters.description: Autonomic prodromes present (nausea, vomiting, feeling warm/cold)

parameters.name: precipitating_factors
parameters.description: Predisposing or precipitating factors present (fear, pain, emotion, orthostasis)

result.name: egsys_score
result.description: EGSYS score for predicting cardiac cause of syncope (range: -2 to +16 points)

ranges.interpretation: Score <3 suggests cardiac syncope is less likely. 21-24 month mortality risk approximately 3%. Continue standard syncope evaluation and consider non-cardiac causes. Outpatient follow-up may be appropriate for stable patients without high-risk features.

Score ≥3 suggests cardiac syncope is likely with 95% sensitivity. 21-24 month mortality risk approximately 17%. Consider hospital admission for diagnostic confirmation. Recommend cardiology consultation and further cardiac evaluation including echocardiogram, telemetry monitoring, and appropriate cardiac testing.

references: Del Rosso A, Ungar A, Maggi R, Giada F, Petix NR, De Santo T, et al. Clinical predictors of cardiac syncope at initial evaluation in patients referred urgently to a general hospital: the EGSYS score. Heart. 2008;94(12):1620-6. doi: 10.1136/hrt.2008.143123.
Kariman H, Harati S, Safari S, Baratloo A, Pishgahi M, Ardalani AR. Validation of EGSYS Score in Prediction of Cardiogenic Syncope. Emerg Med Int. 2015;2015:515370. doi: 10.1155/2015/515370.

Task Force for the Diagnosis and Management of Syncope; European Society of Cardiology (ESC); European Heart Rhythm Association (EHRA); Heart Failure Association (HFA); Heart Rhythm Society (HRS). Guidelines for the diagnosis and management of syncope (version 2009). Eur Heart J. 2009;30(21):2631-71. doi: 10.1093/eurheartj/ehp298.

Brignole M, Moya A, de Lange FJ, Deharo JC, Elliott PM, Fanciulli A, et al. 2018 ESC Guidelines for the diagnosis and management of syncope. Eur Heart J. 2018;39(21):1883-1948. doi: 10.1093/eurheartj/ehy037.
formula: EGSYS Score = (+3 if abnormal EKG/heart disease) + (+4 if palpitations before syncope) + (+3 if syncope during effort) + (+2 if syncope in supine position) + (-1 if autonomic prodromes present) + (-1 if precipitating factors present). Score ≥3 indicates likely cardiac syncope.
notes: The EGSYS score is designed for emergency department screening, not as a substitute for clinical judgment.
Score ≥3 has 95% sensitivity and 61% specificity for cardiac syncope with positive predictive value of 33% and negative predictive value of 99%.
Patients with score ≥3 should be considered for hospital admission and cardiology consultation.
The score helps differentiate between cardiac and non-cardiac causes of syncope.
Higher scores favor cardiac etiology, while lower scores suggest non-cardiac causes.
Autonomic prodromes and precipitating factors actually reduce the likelihood of cardiac cause (negative points).
EKG abnormalities and heart disease are strong predictors of cardiac syncope (+3 points).
Palpitations before syncope are the strongest predictor (+4 points).
Syncope during physical effort suggests cardiac cause (+3 points).
Syncope in supine position is less common in vasovagal syncope (+2 points).
The score has been validated in multiple studies with consistent performance characteristics.
21-24 month mortality is significantly higher in patients with scores ≥3 (17% vs 3%).
The tool is most useful in emergency department settings for initial risk stratification.
Some experts prefer the San Francisco Syncope Rule for syncope risk stratification.
Clinical assessment should always complement the score rather than be replaced by it.
Patients with high-risk features may need admission regardless of EGSYS score.
The score helps guide the intensity of cardiac evaluation needed.
Follow-up studies show sustained prognostic value over extended periods.
